articles.headline: Detainee Deal Comes With Contradictions
articles.snippet: The compromise reached on the interrogations and trials of terrorism suspects is a series of interlocking paradoxes, experts say.
articles.abstract: The compromise reached on the interrogations and trials of terrorism suspects is a series of interlocking paradoxes, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The compromise reached on Thursday between Congressional Republicans and the White House on the interrogations and trials of terrorism suspects is, legal experts said yesterday, a series of interlocking paradoxes.

articles.headline: Click Fraud Is Growing on the Web
articles.snippet: Pay-per-click advertising fraud is becoming more pervasive as spurious clicks can be generated through automated programs.
articles.abstract: Pay-per-click advertising fraud is becoming more pervasive as spurious clicks can be generated through automated programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, DiamondHarmony.com, an online jewelry store, decided that it had outgrown its sole source of advertising, which was eBay. The company added an elaborate marketing effort on search engines that included a pay-per-click advertising campaign based on keywords and phrases. For its trouble, DiamondHarmony became ensnared in click fraud.

articles.headline: Chairwoman Leaves Hewlett in Spying Furor
articles.snippet: Patricia C. Dunn resigned and will be replaced by Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive. Also, two high executives who supervised investigators are said to be leaving.
articles.abstract: Patricia C. Dunn resigned and will be replaced by Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive. Also, two high executives who supervised investigators are said to be leaving.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 22 — The furor over Hewlett-Packard’s spying operation claimed its highest-ranking victim on Friday with the immediate resignation of its chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn.
articles.byline: By Damon Darlin and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Betting the House and Losing Big
articles.snippet: Amaranth Advisors pledges to regain investors’ trust after suffering $6 billion in natural gas trading losses.
articles.abstract: Amaranth Advisors pledges to regain investors’ trust after suffering $6 billion in natural gas trading losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than a week before the hedge fund Amaranth Advisors told investors that it had lost billions of dollars in natural gas trades, Charles H. Winkler, the fund’s chief operating officer, was sipping Australian wine and dining at the Four Seasons restaurant with a handful of prominent hedge fund managers.

articles.headline: Curiosity Has Its Merits and Its Profits
articles.snippet: Hedge funds don’t investigate options backdating just to satisfy their curiosity. Rather, they do it to find an edge — and to use that edge to get richer than they already are.
articles.abstract: Hedge funds don’t investigate options backdating just to satisfy their curiosity. Rather, they do it to find an edge — and to use that edge to get richer than they already are.
articles.lead_paragraph: “I think we’re people who are just curious about things,” said Andrew J. Redleaf, with a tone of mock innocence.

articles.headline: A Stormy Test for Democracy in South Africa
articles.snippet: Some say the bare-knuckled succession struggle for the presidency could foretell how robust South Africa’s young democracy is.
articles.abstract: Some say the bare-knuckled succession struggle for the presidency could foretell how robust South Africa’s young democracy is.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 22 — South Africa’s first democratic president was a foregone conclusion. Its second was anointed with odometer-like predictability. Now for something completely different: a bare-knuckled succession struggle, replete with mudslinging, grandstanding, ideological splits and all the other earmarks of a robust democracy.

articles.headline: Decline in Gas Prices Isn’t Buoying Detroit
articles.snippet: Few in the automotive industry are betting that the latest drop in gas prices will undo the damage done to Detroit.
articles.abstract: Few in the automotive industry are betting that the latest drop in gas prices will undo the damage done to Detroit.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Sept. 22 — Just when $3-a-gallon gasoline looked as if it were here to stay, it left.

articles.headline: Detainee Deal Comes With Contradictions
articles.snippet: The compromise reached on Thursday between Congressional Republicans and the White House on the interrogations and trials of terrorism suspects is, legal experts said yesterday, a series of interlocking paradoxes.      It would impose new legal st...
articles.abstract: The compromise reached on Thursday between Congressional Republicans and the White House on the interrogations and trials of terrorism suspects is, legal experts said yesterday, a series of interlocking paradoxes.      It would impose new legal standards that it forbids the courts to enforce.
articles.lead_paragraph: The compromise reached on Thursday between Congressional Republicans and the White House on the interrogations and trials of terrorism suspects is, legal experts said yesterday, a series of interlocking paradoxes.

articles.headline: A Stormy Test for Democracy in South Africa
articles.snippet: South Africa's first democratic president was a foregone conclusion. Its second was anointed with odometer-like predictability. Now for something completely different: a bare-knuckled succession struggle, replete with mudslinging, grandstanding, i...
articles.abstract: South Africa's first democratic president was a foregone conclusion. Its second was anointed with odometer-like predictability. Now for something completely different: a bare-knuckled succession struggle, replete with mudslinging, grandstanding, ideological splits and all the other earmarks of a robust democracy.     A struggle, some here say, that could foretell just how robust South Africa's young democracy is.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG, Sept. 22 - South Africa's first democratic president was a foregone conclusion. Its second was anointed with odometer-like predictability. Now for something completely different: a bare-knuckled succession struggle, replete with mudslinging, grandstanding, ideological splits and all the other earmarks of a robust democracy.

articles.headline: Chairwoman Leaves Hewlett in Spying Furor
articles.snippet: The furor over Hewlett-Packard's spying operation claimed its highest-ranking victim on Friday with the immediate resignation of its chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn.      The move was announced by Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive, who will now succe...
articles.abstract: The furor over Hewlett-Packard's spying operation claimed its highest-ranking victim on Friday with the immediate resignation of its chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn.      The move was announced by Mark V. Hurd, the chief executive, who will now succeed her. But even as he offered an account of an investigation gone awry, and offered apologies to those whose privacy was invaded, he made it clear that many questions had yet to be answered.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 22 - The furor over Hewlett-Packard's spying operation claimed its highest-ranking victim on Friday with the immediate resignation of its chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn.
articles.byline: By Damon Darlin and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Click Fraud Is Growing on the Web
articles.snippet: Article on growing problem of click fraud, which most commonly happens when renegade partners, who get portion of fees earned by search engine each time paid link is clicked, or rival companies deliberately generate excessive clicks that do not re...
articles.abstract: Article on growing problem of click fraud, which most commonly happens when renegade partners, who get portion of fees earned by search engine each time paid link is clicked, or rival companies deliberately generate excessive clicks that do not result in sales; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, DiamondHarmony.com, an online jewelry store, decided that it had outgrown its sole source of advertising, which was eBay. The company added an elaborate marketing effort on search engines that included a pay-per-click advertising campaign based on keywords and phrases. For its trouble, DiamondHarmony became ensnared in click fraud.

articles.headline: Curiosity Has Its Merits and Its Profits
articles.snippet: Joe Nocera column on Whitebox Advisors hedge fund head Andrew Redleaf and colleagues who conducted independent study on practice of backdating stock options; raises question of whether Redlead conducted study to make market better place or did so ...
articles.abstract: Joe Nocera column on Whitebox Advisors hedge fund head Andrew Redleaf and colleagues who conducted independent study on practice of backdating stock options; raises question of whether Redlead conducted study to make market better place or did so to make money (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: "I think we're people who are just curious about things," said Andrew J. Redleaf, with a tone of mock innocence.

articles.headline: Study Condemns F.D.A.’s Handling of Drug Safety
articles.snippet: The nation's system for ensuring the safety of medicines needs major changes, advertising of new drugs should be restricted, and consumers should be wary of drugs that have only recently been approved, according to a long-anticipated study of drug...
articles.abstract: The nation's system for ensuring the safety of medicines needs major changes, advertising of new drugs should be restricted, and consumers should be wary of drugs that have only recently been approved, according to a long-anticipated study of drug safety.     The report by the Institute of Medicine, part of the National Academy of Sciences, is likely to intensify a debate about the safety of the nation's drug supply and the adequacy of the government's oversight. The debate heated up in September 2004 when Merck withdrew its popular arthritis drug Vioxx after studies showed that it doubled the risks of heart attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 - The nation's system for ensuring the safety of medicines needs major changes, advertising of new drugs should be restricted, and consumers should be wary of drugs that have only recently been approved, according to a long-anticipated study of drug safety.

articles.headline: Betting the House and Losing Big
articles.snippet: Article on meltdown at Amaranth Advisors, one of hottest hedge funds of recent years, as natural gas prices slumped; photos; graph (M)

articles.headline: Decline in Gas Prices Isn’t Buoying Detroit
articles.snippet: Many auto dealers and auto executives say it is unlikely, now that gas prices have fallen almost 50 cents in last month, that shoppers will once again favor SUV's and other big vehicles over smaller cars; consumers may have decided that higher gas...
articles.abstract: Many auto dealers and auto executives say it is unlikely, now that gas prices have fallen almost 50 cents in last month, that shoppers will once again favor SUV's and other big vehicles over smaller cars; consumers may have decided that higher gas prices are inevitable while Detroit car companies continue to focus on big vehicles; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Sept. 22 - Just when $3-a-gallon gasoline looked as if it were here to stay, it left.

articles.abstract: There is a slight uptick in the number of men who provide early childhood care or education to children 5 and younger.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like the character played by Eddie Murphy in “Daddy Day Care,” Todd Cole needed the push of a layoff to join the small number of men who work as child care providers.

articles.headline: Spy Agencies Say Iraq War Worsens Terrorism Threat
articles.snippet: A stark assessment has found that the American invasion and occupation of Iraq has helped spawn a new generation of Islamic radicalism and that the overall terrorist threat has grown since the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.abstract: A stark assessment has found that the American invasion and occupation of Iraq has helped spawn a new generation of Islamic radicalism and that the overall terrorist threat has grown since the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 — A stark assessment of terrorism trends by American intelligence agencies has found that the American invasion and occupation of Iraq has helped spawn a new generation of Islamic radicalism and that the overall terrorist threat has grown since the Sept. 11 attacks.

articles.snippet: Are kennel amenities for the pet’s benefit, or the pet owner’s?
articles.abstract: Are kennel amenities for the pet’s benefit, or the pet owner’s?
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW GERMANY, Minn.

articles.headline: That Back-to-School Feeling
articles.snippet: Years after graduation, there's still an annual longing for a clean slate.
articles.abstract: Years after graduation, there's still an annual longing for a clean slate.
articles.lead_paragraph: AT this time of year, nearly every year, I get the feeling that something is left undone. Though it happens like clockwork, it somehow always comes as a surprise, a nagging sense of a shoelace still untied, a door still ajar, a bill overdue.

articles.headline: So Small a Town, So Many Patent Suits
articles.snippet: Marshall, Tex., population 25,000, is arguably the patent lawsuit capital of the nation, where plaintiffs know they are more likely to get a favorable judgment.
articles.abstract: Marshall, Tex., population 25,000, is arguably the patent lawsuit capital of the nation, where plaintiffs know they are more likely to get a favorable judgment.

articles.snippet: Federal lawmakers aim to close a legal loophole that has left the electronic energy markets to pretty much regulate themselves.
articles.abstract: Federal lawmakers aim to close a legal loophole that has left the electronic energy markets to pretty much regulate themselves.

articles.abstract: The Islamists in Mogadishu seem to be trying to increase public support by softening their views, at least officially.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Sept. 23 — As the sun begins to sink over this broken city, work crews swing their axes over their shoulders and head home.

articles.headline: As Children Suffer, Parents Agonize Over Spinach
articles.snippet: Around the country, some families still wait by bedsides, wondering which foods they could again feel safe giving their children.
articles.abstract: Around the country, some families still wait by bedsides, wondering which foods they could again feel safe giving their children.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 22  The hardest moment came when Elaine and Dennis Krause’s 9-year-son, who had stoically undergone kidney dialysis, blood transfusions and drug treatments that made him hallucinate that spiders were all around him, quietly asked his parents whether he was going to die.

articles.headline: For N.F.L., Crowd Noise Is a Headache
articles.snippet: National Football League has long had uneasy relationship with crowd noise; may attempt to overcome it by allowing visiting players benefit of helmet-to-helmet wireless communications to help them avoid false-start penalties caused by miscommunica...

articles.lead_paragraph: At most big ballgames, noise is good, and more noise is better.

articles.abstract: More patent lawsuits will be filed in federal court in Marshall, Texas, than district courts in San Francisco, Chicago, New York City and Washington combined; Los Angeles Central District of California is only district in nation that will handle more patent infringement cases; lawyers cite fast trials and plaintiff-friendly juries, with patent holders winning 78 percent of decisions; history of city is given; photos; graph (M)

articles.headline: Spy Agencies Say Iraq War Worsens Terrorism Threat
articles.snippet: Classified National Intelligence Estimate finds that Iraq war has played more direct role in fueling Islamic radicalism than acknowledged in recent Bush administration or House Intelligence Committee report; previous drafts of National Intelligenc...
articles.abstract: Classified National Intelligence Estimate finds that Iraq war has played more direct role in fueling Islamic radicalism than acknowledged in recent Bush administration or House Intelligence Committee report; previous drafts of National Intelligence Estimate described specific actions that are believed to have stoked jihad movement, like detention of prisoners at Abu Ghraib and Guantanamo Bay Naval Base, but it is unclear if final draft criticizes individual US policies (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - A stark assessment of terrorism trends by American intelligence agencies has found that the American invasion and occupation of Iraq has helped spawn a new generation of Islamic radicalism and that the overall terrorist threat has grown since the Sept. 11 attacks.

articles.headline: Islamists Calm Somali Capital With Restraint
articles.snippet: Islamists in control of Mogadishu, Somalia, have pacified one of most dangerous cities in world and seem to have moderated their message to increase public support; are operating in almost campaign mode, delivering social services and pushing for ...
articles.abstract: Islamists in control of Mogadishu, Somalia, have pacified one of most dangerous cities in world and seem to have moderated their message to increase public support; are operating in almost campaign mode, delivering social services and pushing for democratic elections; hard-core militiamen still operate, but leaders say they are rogue elements who will be punished; United States continues to assert that Islamists are sheltering Al Qaeda terrorists; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Sept. 23 - As the sun begins to sink over this broken city, work crews swing their axes over their shoulders and head home.

articles.headline: Lung Patients See a New Era of Transplants
articles.snippet: Recent changes have revitalized lung transplantation by putting patients who need transplants most and are most likely to benefit from them at top of list; lungs previously went to whoever had been on list longest; changes have resulted in shorter...
articles.abstract: Recent changes have revitalized lung transplantation by putting patients who need transplants most and are most likely to benefit from them at top of list; lungs previously went to whoever had been on list longest; changes have resulted in shorter waits and more lung transplants, all but erasing need for transplants from live donors; another major change is greater availability of lungs from cadavers as more people become organ donors and doctors learn new techniques for salvaging lungs; graphs; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: A quiet revolution in the world of lung transplants is saving the lives of people who, just two years ago, would have died on the waiting list.

articles.headline: Dangers of a World Without Rules
articles.snippet: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column discusses how commodities regulators allowed Amaranth Advisors hedge fund to amass huge impact on energy prices; examines effects of Commodity Futures Modernization Act; Amaranth Advisors lost $6 billion for its...
articles.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column discusses how commodities regulators allowed Amaranth Advisors hedge fund to amass huge impact on energy prices; examines effects of Commodity Futures Modernization Act; Amaranth Advisors lost $6 billion for its investors by betting heavily on gas futures; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: IT was just another ho-hum week on Wall Street: the Federal Reserve held rates steady, stocks were about flat -- and a hedge fund called Amaranth Advisors lost $6 billion.

articles.headline: A Dog’s Life, Upgraded
articles.snippet: Boarding industry for pets is experiencing sweeping changes as upscale luxury kennels are opening for dogs; Top Dog Country Club features artificial-turf lawn, play yard and tiled, in-ground heated swimming pool; activities match those humans woul...
articles.abstract: Boarding industry for pets is experiencing sweeping changes as upscale luxury kennels are opening for dogs; Top Dog Country Club features artificial-turf lawn, play yard and tiled, in-ground heated swimming pool; activities match those humans would find at their own resorts; American Pet Products Manufacturers Association estimates people will spend $34.8 billion on their pets in 2006, with $2.7 billion going toward grooming and boarding; photos; graph (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW GERMANY, Minn. - ON a sunny day in August, a half-dozen large dogs -- mostly Labrador retrievers -- bounded in and out of the swimming pool here at Top Dog Country Club. Others lounged on the artificial-turf lawn, or looked on with envy and vocal protests from "time out" pens on the edge of the play yard.

articles.headline: Rumsfeld Also Plays Hardball on Squash Courts
articles.snippet: Pentagon officials and employees say Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld's play on Pentagon's squash courts closely resembles way he has run Defense Dept; asserts that Rumsfeld is stubbornly competitive and has seemingly limitless stamina, but does not ...
articles.abstract: Pentagon officials and employees say Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld's play on Pentagon's squash courts closely resembles way he has run Defense Dept; asserts that Rumsfeld is stubbornly competitive and has seemingly limitless stamina, but does not play by rules; hols that does not try tricky bank shots, but plays ball hard and ends point quickly; contend that relentlessly attacks his opponent's confidence; photos; diagram (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 - For the last six years, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld has slipped down to the Pentagon basement many afternoons, changed into a T-shirt, sweat pants and headband, and spent a heart-thumping hour playing squash.

articles.headline: As Children Suffer, Parents Agonize Over Spinach
articles.snippet: National outbreak of E. coli linked to fresh spinach grown in California has sickened 170 people in 25 states and killed at least one person; sudden, mysterious illness has struck most often in homes of those who view themselves as health-consciou...
articles.abstract: National outbreak of E. coli linked to fresh spinach grown in California has sickened 170 people in 25 states and killed at least one person; sudden, mysterious illness has struck most often in homes of those who view themselves as health-conscious; more than half of cases so far have required hospitalization; children and oldest adults are typically most vulnerable but more than 70 percent of victims in latest outbreak are somewhere in between; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 22 - The hardest moment came when Elaine and Dennis Krause's 9-year-son, who had stoically undergone kidney dialysis, blood transfusions and drug treatments that made him hallucinate that spiders were all around him, quietly asked his parents whether he was going to die.

articles.headline: A Senator Bets on Party’s Clout in Pennsylvania
articles.snippet: The Senate race in Pennsylvania, where Senator Rick Santorum lags behind his Democratic challenger, State Treasurer Bob Casey, in the polls, will put Republican fortifications to the test.
articles.abstract: The Senate race in Pennsylvania, where Senator Rick Santorum lags behind his Democratic challenger, State Treasurer Bob Casey, in the polls, will put Republican fortifications to the test.
articles.lead_paragraph: An endangered Republican like Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania could always comfort himself with this: The political winds may be blowing the Democrats’ way this year, but the Republicans retain some formidable structural advantages.

articles.headline: An Obsession With Leaks and Plugs
articles.snippet: Events of the past few weeks have shown that leaks tend to afflict ships that aren’t seaworthy to begin with, and tend to bring out the panicky worst in people.
articles.abstract: Events of the past few weeks have shown that leaks tend to afflict ships that aren’t seaworthy to begin with, and tend to bring out the panicky worst in people.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been a busy week for leaks, a particularly apt metaphor for the events at Hewlett-Packard and in a San Francisco courtroom. First, leaks tend to afflict ships that aren’t seaworthy to begin with. Second, leaks — by definition a nasty surprise — tend to bring out the panicky worst in people.

articles.headline: Not So Funny Anymore: Squabbling and Spiraling Costs Dissolve a Comedy Mill
articles.snippet: Jim Carrey's recent move to the Creative Artists Agency signaled changing times for a tight network of stars who have dominated Hollywood comedies for several years.
articles.abstract: Jim Carrey's recent move to the Creative Artists Agency signaled changing times for a tight network of stars who have dominated Hollywood comedies for several years.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Jim Carrey picked up the phone to call his agent, Nick Stevens, earlier this month, it was the end of a long, profitable run.

articles.headline: Unit Makes Do as Army Strives to Plug Gaps
articles.snippet: The pressures on the Army are apparent in the Third Infantry Division, which is preparing to go back to Iraq.
articles.abstract: The pressures on the Army are apparent in the Third Infantry Division, which is preparing to go back to Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: As Iraqi Lights Flicker, ‘Generator Man’ Feels Heat
articles.snippet: When the power goes out in Baghdad, Iraqis blame the generator man, probably the most vilified figure after Saddam Hussein.
articles.abstract: When the power goes out in Baghdad, Iraqis blame the generator man, probably the most vilified figure after Saddam Hussein.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — In offices across Iraq, a ritual plays out every morning during the hottest months. Haggard employees drag themselves into the room, mumble a pleasantry or two and slump into their chairs, moaning about what a bad night’s sleep they had: the power went out, the backup generator was broken, the heat was unbearable, the baby would not stop crying, mosquitoes were everywhere.

articles.headline: Bouquet of Roses May Have Note: ‘Made in China’
articles.snippet: China’s elaborate effort to supply cut flowers to the world also aims to bring jobs and wealth to its impoverished heartland.
articles.abstract: China’s elaborate effort to supply cut flowers to the world also aims to bring jobs and wealth to its impoverished heartland.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUNMING, China — Americans and Europeans are used to buying mass produced shoes, toys and microwave ovens from China. So why not roses?

articles.headline: At Hewlett-Packard, a Chief Wounded by Divided Attention
articles.snippet: Mark V. Hurd has transformed Hewlett-Packard into a growth company, but the success is being overshadowed by the company’s leak scandal.
articles.abstract: Mark V. Hurd has transformed Hewlett-Packard into a growth company, but the success is being overshadowed by the company’s leak scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 22 — Mark V. Hurd sat at the head of the table in the Hewlett-Packard boardroom, the room that had been the source of leaks and the starting point of a misguided and ultimately embarrassing attempt to plug them.

articles.headline: U.N. Force Is Treading Lightly on Lebanese Soil
articles.snippet: Members of the international force say their mission is defined more by what they cannot do than by what they can.
articles.abstract: Members of the international force say their mission is defined more by what they cannot do than by what they can.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIBNIN, Lebanon, Sept. 24 — One month after a United Nations Security Council resolution ended a 34-day war between Israel and Lebanon’s Hezbollah militia, members of the international force sent to help keep the peace say their mission is defined more by what they cannot do than by what they can.

articles.headline: Technology for Spying Lures More Than Military
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard is not the only company diving into the murky world of private investigators and secret surveillance.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard is not the only company diving into the murky world of private investigators and secret surveillance.

articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Ron Stodghill

articles.headline: Young Internet Producers, Bankrolled, Are Seeking Act II
articles.snippet: The creators of Digg, the Internet news aggregation site, have secured financing to turn their Internet-based video production firm into a full-fledged company.
articles.abstract: The creators of Digg, the Internet news aggregation site, have secured financing to turn their Internet-based video production firm into a full-fledged company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 — Silicon Valley is awash in serial entrepreneurs, those who start a company, run it for a while, and then after success, failure or something in between, move on and start again.

articles.headline: U.N. Force Is Treading Lightly on Lebanese Soil
articles.snippet: One month after a United Nations Security Council resolution ended a 34-day war between Israel and Lebanon's Hezbollah militia, members of the international force sent to help keep the peace say their mission is defined more by what they cannot do...
articles.abstract: One month after a United Nations Security Council resolution ended a 34-day war between Israel and Lebanon's Hezbollah militia, members of the international force sent to help keep the peace say their mission is defined more by what they cannot do than by what they can.     They say they cannot set up checkpoints, search cars, homes or businesses or detain suspects. If they see a truck transporting missiles, for example, they say they can not stop it. They cannot do any of this, they say, because under their interpretation of the Security Council resolution that deployed them, they must first be authorized to take such action by the Lebanese Army.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIBNIN, Lebanon, Sept. 24 - One month after a United Nations Security Council resolution ended a 34-day war between Israel and Lebanon's Hezbollah militia, members of the international force sent to help keep the peace say their mission is defined more by what they cannot do than by what they can.

articles.headline: As Iraqi Lights Flicker, ‘Generator Man’ Feels Heat
articles.snippet: In offices across Iraq, a ritual plays out every morning during the hottest months. Haggard employees drag themselves into the room, mumble a pleasantry or two and slump into their chairs, moaning about what a bad night's sleep they had: the power...
articles.abstract: In offices across Iraq, a ritual plays out every morning during the hottest months. Haggard employees drag themselves into the room, mumble a pleasantry or two and slump into their chairs, moaning about what a bad night's sleep they had: the power went out, the backup generator was broken, the heat was unbearable, the baby would not stop crying, mosquitoes were everywhere.      Inevitably, these grievances, like hornets, will gather in a single cloud of fury and swoop down on one target: the generator man, probably the most vilified figure in Iraqi society after Saddam Hussein.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD - In offices across Iraq, a ritual plays out every morning during the hottest months. Haggard employees drag themselves into the room, mumble a pleasantry or two and slump into their chairs, moaning about what a bad night's sleep they had: the power went out, the backup generator was broken, the heat was unbearable, the baby would not stop crying, mosquitoes were everywhere.

articles.headline: Bouquet of Roses May Have Note: ‘Made in China’
articles.snippet: Americans and Europeans are used to buying mass produced shoes, toys and microwave ovens from China. So why not roses?     That is the thinking behind an elaborate Chinese government effort to export cut flowers, aimed not just at developing a new...
articles.abstract: Americans and Europeans are used to buying mass produced shoes, toys and microwave ovens from China. So why not roses?     That is the thinking behind an elaborate Chinese government effort to export cut flowers, aimed not just at developing a new business to take on the world but at redeveloping the social and economic landscape here in southwestern China.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUNMING, China - Americans and Europeans are used to buying mass produced shoes, toys and microwave ovens from China. So why not roses?

articles.headline: In Tiny Courts of N.Y., Abuses of Law and Power
articles.snippet: Some of the courtrooms are not even courtrooms: tiny offices or basement rooms without a judge's bench or jury box. Sometimes the public is not admitted, witnesses are not sworn to tell the truth, and there is no word-for-word record of the procee...
articles.abstract: Some of the courtrooms are not even courtrooms: tiny offices or basement rooms without a judge's bench or jury box. Sometimes the public is not admitted, witnesses are not sworn to tell the truth, and there is no word-for-word record of the proceedings.     Nearly three-quarters of the judges are not lawyers, and many -- truck drivers, sewer workers or laborers -- have scant grasp of the most basic legal principles. Some never got through high school, and at least one went no further than grade school.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the courtrooms are not even courtrooms: tiny offices or basement rooms without a judge's bench or jury box. Sometimes the public is not admitted, witnesses are not sworn to tell the truth, and there is no word-for-word record of the proceedings.

articles.headline: Not So Funny Anymore: Squabbling and Spiraling Costs Dissolve a Comedy Mill
articles.snippet: When Jim Carrey picked up the phone to call his agent, Nick Stevens, earlier this month, it was the end of a long, profitable run.      The comedy superstar called Mr. Stevens, who had represented him for 15 years, guiding his success from ''In Li...
articles.abstract: When Jim Carrey picked up the phone to call his agent, Nick Stevens, earlier this month, it was the end of a long, profitable run.      The comedy superstar called Mr. Stevens, who had represented him for 15 years, guiding his success from ''In Living Color'' on television to ''Ace Ventura'' in movies to a rare stratosphere of $20 million roles, to tell him that his services were no longer required. Instead, Mr. Carrey was moving on to that sprawling behemoth of Hollywood talent agencies, the Creative Artists Agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES - When Jim Carrey picked up the phone to call his agent, Nick Stevens, earlier this month, it was the end of a long, profitable run.

articles.headline: An Obsession With Leaks and Plugs
articles.snippet: It's been a busy week for leaks, a particularly apt metaphor for the events at Hewlett-Packard and in a San Francisco courtroom. First, leaks tend to afflict ships that aren't seaworthy to begin with. Second, leaks -- by definition a nasty surpris...
articles.abstract: It's been a busy week for leaks, a particularly apt metaphor for the events at Hewlett-Packard and in a San Francisco courtroom. First, leaks tend to afflict ships that aren't seaworthy to begin with. Second, leaks -- by definition a nasty surprise -- tend to bring out the panicky worst in people.      At Hewlett-Packard, the company's leadership responded to leaks on its own corporate board by ordering all hands to grab buckets and immediately start bailing water -- into the boat. For two years, with its chief ethics officer often riding point, the company commissioned a set of black ops that included internal witch hunts, surveillance and warrantless searches of reporters' phone records, all in an effort to zealously guard the image of their company
articles.lead_paragraph: It's been a busy week for leaks, a particularly apt metaphor for the events at Hewlett-Packard and in a San Francisco courtroom. First, leaks tend to afflict ships that aren't seaworthy to begin with. Second, leaks -- by definition a nasty surprise -- tend to bring out the panicky worst in people.

articles.headline: Technology for Spying Lures More Than Military
articles.snippet: In the world of security sleuths and private investigators, it's billed as one of the biggest events of the year. Some 20,000 experts in the business are gathering this week in San Diego to check out the latest in high-tech surveillance gadgets an...
articles.abstract: In the world of security sleuths and private investigators, it's billed as one of the biggest events of the year. Some 20,000 experts in the business are gathering this week in San Diego to check out the latest in high-tech surveillance gadgets and sit in on seminars discussing undercover investigations, background checks and interrogation techniques.     One of the keynote speakers is George J. Tenet, the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Ron Stodghill

articles.headline: Young Internet Producers, Bankrolled, Are Seeking Act II
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley is awash in serial entrepreneurs, those who start a company, run it for a while, and then after success, failure or something in between, move on and start again.      Jay Adelson, 36, and Kevin Rose, 29, are parallel entrepreneurs ...
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley is awash in serial entrepreneurs, those who start a company, run it for a while, and then after success, failure or something in between, move on and start again.      Jay Adelson, 36, and Kevin Rose, 29, are parallel entrepreneurs -- starting a second company just as the first one is taking off.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 - Silicon Valley is awash in serial entrepreneurs, those who start a company, run it for a while, and then after success, failure or something in between, move on and start again.

articles.headline: A Senator Bets on Party’s Clout in Pennsylvania
articles.snippet: An endangered Republican like Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania could always comfort himself with this: The political winds may be blowing the Democrats' way this year, but the Republicans retain some formidable structural advantages.     Like...
articles.abstract: An endangered Republican like Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania could always comfort himself with this: The political winds may be blowing the Democrats' way this year, but the Republicans retain some formidable structural advantages.     Like money: Mr. Santorum, the third-ranking Republican in the Senate leadership, has had a significant fund-raising advantage over his Democratic challenger, State Treasurer Bob Casey, which means more money for television advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: An endangered Republican like Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania could always comfort himself with this: The political winds may be blowing the Democrats' way this year, but the Republicans retain some formidable structural advantages.

articles.headline: At Hewlett-Packard, a Chief Wounded by Divided Attention
articles.snippet: Mark V. Hurd sat at the head of the table in the Hewlett-Packard boardroom, the room that had been the source of leaks and the starting point of a misguided and ultimately embarrassing attempt to plug them.     Mr. Hurd, the chief executive, had w...
articles.abstract: Mark V. Hurd sat at the head of the table in the Hewlett-Packard boardroom, the room that had been the source of leaks and the starting point of a misguided and ultimately embarrassing attempt to plug them.     Mr. Hurd, the chief executive, had wanted to talk about the transformation inside Hewlett-Packard, how it was becoming a lean Silicon Valley growth company instead of a cash cow content to thrive on the high profit margins of its ink and toner cartridges.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 22 - Mark V. Hurd sat at the head of the table in the Hewlett-Packard boardroom, the room that had been the source of leaks and the starting point of a misguided and ultimately embarrassing attempt to plug them.

articles.headline: Unit Makes Do as Army Strives to Plug Gaps
articles.snippet: The pressures that the conflict in Iraq is putting on the Army are apparent amid the towering pine trees of southeast Georgia, where the Third Infantry Division is preparing for the likelihood that it will go back to Iraq for a third tour.     Col...
articles.abstract: The pressures that the conflict in Iraq is putting on the Army are apparent amid the towering pine trees of southeast Georgia, where the Third Infantry Division is preparing for the likelihood that it will go back to Iraq for a third tour.     Col. Tom James, who commands the division's Second Brigade, acknowledged that his unit's equipment levels had fallen so low that it now had no tanks or other armored vehicles to use in training and that his soldiers were rated as largely untrained in attack and defense.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
